abstract_summ: BACKGROUND: The COVID-19 pandemic has aggregated mental health sufferings throughout the entire world.Although COVID-19-related anxieties were shared by pregnant women characterised by diverse sociodemographic variables, with very small nuances, Arab women were more anxious about each of the issues than Jewish women.Results revealed that 36.6% of participants showed psychological distress due to the COVID-19 pandemic.The fact that little is yet known about the possible implications of COVID-19 for pregnancy, puts pregnant women at greater risk of heightened anxiety and psychological distress.In relation to gender, data indicate that men have higher levels of depression than women, and similar levels of anxiety and stress.
title_summ: The German COVID-19 Survey on Mental Health: Primary ResultsUniversity students’ mental health amidst the COVID-19 quarantine in GreeceExploring COVID-19 stress and its factors in Bangladesh: A perception-based studyPsychological Symptoms During the Two Stages of Lockdown in Response to the COVID-19 Outbreak:Distress and anxiety associated with COVID-19 among Jewish and Arab pregnant women in Israel.Psychological impact of COVID-19 in Spain: Early data report.An Investigation in a Sample of Citizens in Northern Spain
title_abstract_phrases: A perception-based studyBACKGROUND: The COVID-19 pandemic has aggregated mental health sufferings throughout the entire world.Although COVID-19-related anxieties were shared by pregnant women characterised by diverse sociodemographic variables, with very small nuances, Arab women were more anxious about each of the issues than Jewish women.INTRODUCTION The fact that little is yet known about the possible implications of COVID-19 for pregnancy, puts pregnant women at greater risk of heightened anxiety and psychological distress.DISCUSSION Our findings highlight the importance of assessing anxiety and distress in pregnant women during the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as the need to be attentive to the double stress of pregnant women in times of crisis and to the potential vulnerability of subgroups, such as cultural minorities.CONCLUSIONS: Considering the present findings, it is essential to introduce time-oriented policy, and implement care monitoring plans in the country, which may help in managing the pandemic as well as nurturing the public mental health to combat COVID-19 related psychological challenges.
